definitions.definition: to come together, or bring people together, in one place to form a group

examples.text: A **crowd** soon **gathered**.
His supporters gathered in the main square.
Can you all **gather round**? I've got something to tell you.
The whole family **gathered together** at Ray's home.
They were all **gathered round** the TV.
A large crowd was gathered outside the studio.
The kids were **gathered together** in one room.
They are all gathering for a major conference.
The boys gathered around the car.

definitions.definition: to bring things together that have been spread around

examples.text: People slowly gathered their belongings and left the hall.
I waited while he gathered up his papers.
She gathered her things together and got to her feet.

definitions.definition: to collect information from different sources

examples.text: to **gather information/data/intelligence**
Detectives have spent months **gathering evidence**.

definitions.definition: to collect plants, fruit, etc. from a wide area

examples.text: to gather wild flowers
They lived in the forest, gathering mushrooms and berries to eat.

definitions.definition: to pick or cut and collect crops to be stored

examples.text: It was late August and the harvest had been safely gathered in.

definitions.definition: to believe or understand that something is true because of information or evidence you have

examples.text: I gather (that) you wanted to see me.
I gather from your email that you're not enjoying your job.
‘There's been a delay.’ ‘I gathered that.’
‘She won't be coming.’ ‘**So I gather**.’
You're self-employed, I gather.
**As far as I can gather**, he got involved in a fight.
**From what I can gather**, there's been some kind of problem.

definitions.definition: to increase in speed, force, etc.

examples.text: The truck gathered speed.
During the 1980s the green movement **gathered momentum**.
Thousands of these machines are **gathering dust** *(= not being used)* in stockrooms.
As the weeks passed, Charlotte began to gather strength.

definitions.definition: to gradually increase in number or amount

examples.text: The storm clouds were gathering.
the gathering gloom of a winter’s afternoon

definitions.definition: to pull a piece of clothing tighter to your body
definitions.sensetop: gather something around you/somethinggather something up

examples.text: He gathered his cloak around him.
She gathered up her skirts and ran.

definitions.definition: to pull parts of a piece of clothing together in folds and sew them in place

examples.text: She wore a skirt gathered (in) at the waist.

definitions.definition: to pull somebody towards you and put your arms around them

examples.text: She gathered the child in her arms and held him close.
He gathered her to him.
I gathered her close and kissed her.

definitions.definition: to prepare yourself to do something that requires effort

examples.text: I sat down for a moment to gather my strength.
She was still trying to gather her thoughts together when the door opened.
Fortunately the short delay gave him time to gather himself.

definitions.definition: to get your breath back after an effort

examples.text: He paused to gather his breath.

definitions.definition: to not be used for a long time

examples.text: That guitar's been sitting there gathering dust for years now.
Play your guitar that's gathering dust, or pull out the old tennis racket for a match.
You may already have an old laptop that is collecting dust but otherwise usable.

definitions.definition: a person who moves from place to place, job to job, etc. does not have a lot of money, possessions or friends but is free from responsibilities

wordOrigin: Old English gaderian, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch gaderen, also to together.
